It is unfortunate that it took the use of chemical weapons to draw a "red line" in the Syrian Civil War. When you have roughly 2,5 million refugees and a death toll over 100,000 people, the use of a particular type of weapon that killed 1-3% doesn't seem right. I do not believe intervention in a civil war should be taken lightly, but if it weren't for the French the United States  might not have obtained independence, if it weren't for the British, Greece would not have obtained independence, so on and so forth. Outside influence is sometimes necessary.

Getting involved in an armed conflict is always a difficult choice. It seems as if the US, the UN, and NATO get overly entangled in political games. While I believe that President Obama has the purest intentions on the matter, it being a difficult conflict to engage in, the "red line" seemed like an excuse not to get involved earlier. Waiting for the use of chemical weapons to make it a hard line issue doesn't seem right.

Most definitely, certain types of weapons receive a different level of attention. I couldn't agree more with the statements both Jimmy Carter and President Obama made regarding the use of chemical weapons. I simply disagree that the other 100,000 that were killed prior did not justify the same attention. The mass exit of over 2,5 million refugees due to the conditions of the civil war should be enough of a sign for the need for intervention. 

The reasons we get involved in international affairs, and the means of how we chose to get involved seem to be a political chess match, and if there is not enough gain on our behalf, we let innocent people die.

It is a difficult choice to get involved in any way in any manor, but I think our government, the UN and NATO have failed the Syrian people in allowing President Bashar al-Assad to slaughter his own people. 

We fear aiding the "wrong side" but if we truly believe in democracy, we should want the people to have the right to have the leaders they wish in place. President Bashar al-Assad has overstayed his welcome, and the "red line" should have been drawn sooner.

, I have no issues with restriction-free social contracts between 2 or more competent and consenting adult individuals. Historically, marriages have always been a religious ceremony conducted by a religious leader in front of several witnesses, so I never understood why our ancestors allowed our secular government to become involved in the defining (a very narrow, restricted, and Christian definition) the only legally accepted social "marriage" contract.
